data.title: April McKinney
data.meta_description: Fresh and delicious recipes from award winning cook and food personality, April McKinney
data.text:
This week my guest is Meredith Andrews, she is a singer/songwriter, wife, and mom to 3. You have probably heard several of Meredith‚Äôs songs including ‚ÄúNot for a Moment,‚Äù ‚ÄúSpirit of the Living God,‚Äù and several of the songs form the Belonging Co‚Äôs most recent AMAZING album. I was surprised to have so much in common with Meredith, and the season she is in spoke so much to the season that so many of us (moms especially) find ourselves in these days. Juggling the full time job of being a wife and mom, as well as pursuing God sized dreams, but also trusting Him in the waiting.

Meredith talked about her journey to becoming a successful Christian music artist and how she attempts to balance her life with her family and this demanding career. She shed some serious wisdom about trusting God with your dreams and not forcing and pushing our way through to the outcome we think we want. I know you will love Meredith and our sincere and authentic conversation!

Links from the Show:

MeredithAndrews.com

Follow Meredith on Instagram

The book we discussed ‚Äì Anonymous

Follow April on Instagram

As promised, Episode 19 is Part 2 with Stephanie Meek, owner with her husband, Isaac, of Five Daughters Bakery and momma to 5 daughters! This one is for the mommas, the pregnant ones and the ones in the trenches with little ones. This lady exudes joy, and I loved hearing from her all about her experiences with pregnancy and mothering little people. She obviously has lots of experience, and I was soaking up her knowledge and advice on she does it.

She is a rockstar and I know you will benefit from her wisdom in the area of motherhood. I‚Äôll be listening to this one again and again as I enter into a new season of mothering 2 kiddos! Send this one to a mom of littles or a pregnant mom, they will be blessed and inspired!

Show Notes:

Supernatural Childbirth book

Today is the BIG day!!!

Today is the long awaited (at least at my house) release day for The Outdoor Table! This book has been almost two years in the making, and I am humbled and so very excited that today has come. Get one for yourself, and perhaps one for dad for Father‚Äôs Day too, it‚Äôs filled with lots of great grilling recipes! So, I‚Äôve talked about the book so much on here, and I really hope you‚Äôll buy it, because it truly is a wonderful book. But today I want to share a little bit of the story behind the book‚Ä¶

I‚Äôm telling you, if you would have told me 5 years ago that I would author a cookbook, like a real cookbook sold in stores nationwide ‚Äì I would‚Äôve thought you were totally crazy. This whole cooking journey I have been on has been the craziest ride of my life. There have been some amazing highs, but there have also been some pretty low lows. I‚Äôve spent many days doubting myself and my ability, wondering if I was being completely unrealistic, feeling like I should just get a ‚Äúreal job,‚Äù and asking God if all of this will ever to amount to anything?

Contrary to what people might think, I haven‚Äôt had this whole cooking journey planned out, it‚Äôs been a roller coaster. There is absolutely no doubt in my mind that God has led me through each door to get to this point. Everytime I considered just giving up, the Lord gave me a little reassurance to keep going. Even if it was a small thing, He would open a door right when I needed it, and I would walk through it.

I have had lots of ideas that didn‚Äôt work out, I‚Äôve gotten my hopes up about the possibility of things that didn‚Äôt happen, and I‚Äôve tried to force things that just weren‚Äôt working. And I will do all of that again I‚Äôm sure, but sometimes pieces of the dream actually do happen, and this cookbook is one of those pieces. People always ask me, ‚Äúso what is your end goal with all of this?‚Äù And I have had a hard time answering that question. There are many things I would love to do, but the bottom line is, I‚Äôm not driving this boat. I had no idea a cookbook would‚Äôve been part of the plan, but that just goes to show, it‚Äôs really not my plan at all. The Lord led me here and, to be honest, I don‚Äôt know where I‚Äôll end up next, and I‚Äôm [finally] okay with that. His plans have always been better than mine anyway.

I suppose I say all of this to encourage anyone out there who has a dream. If you feel like God is calling you to something, even if you don‚Äôt know what the end result looks like, just follow in the direction of that dream. I do believe God places dreams and ideas in our hearts, and if He has a plan for you and you say yes to Him, that‚Äôs an unstoppable force. Ultimately, I want this book to be used for His glory. Even if it is a cookbook, the story behind it, is one of redemption and new life. He took food, the thing that could‚Äôve destroyed me through years of disordered eating, and He gave me total freedom. What the enemy meant for evil, the Lord has used for good in my life.

That‚Äôs the real story here, and I am grateful and humbled beyond words. He is good, and He deserves my praise every hour of every day.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs a shame when we box up hospitality in entertaining. We lose sight of the true spiritual significance behind it, and in doing so we rob ourselves and others of the blessings God intends to come through it.‚Äù -Logan Wolfram, From the She Reads Truth Hospitality study

I just love a good chicken leg, it comes with a handle after all! Even back in the day when we would get a bucket of KFC fried chicken after church, I always preferred the legs. So, in honor of my love for legs, I‚Äôm sharing my Sticky Sesame Chicken Leg recipe! You may have seen some similar recipes to this on Pinterest, but this is my version of the mouth waveringly delicious, Asian flared main dish.

You have probably noticed that lately I have had some type of story to go with my recipes. Over the past few days, I‚Äôve been thinking on what to write for this post, and I got nothin! Ever since I have been getting more personal on here, I‚Äôve waited to write a post until I felt like God was really speaking to me and guiding my writing. I kept coming back to this one, and I finally decided I was just going to publish it today without anything extra. And then, this morning, I read my She Reads Truth devotional and boom, God gave me something! I love when He does that, sometimes I go for days where I just can‚Äôt hear Him, but He always shows up at just the right time.

If you haven‚Äôt checked out the She Reads Truth app, you should, it‚Äôs an awesome women‚Äôs devotional app with all kinds of different studies to choose from. I am currently doing a study on hospitality, and as I read the one for today, I realized that I use the word ‚Äúentertaining‚Äù quite a bit, when what I really mean is hospitality. As you might have guessed, we haven‚Äôt been doing much entertaining since Maverick was born. We haven‚Äôt thrown any Pinterest worthy dinner parties, and I haven‚Äôt hosted a fancy ladies‚Äô brunch. It just feels like I can‚Äôt really entertain right now, because we are in such a busy season of our lives. My husband, Zach, is finishing up building his first house, I‚Äôm listing it this month, my cookbook is coming out soon, and of course Maverick complicates things a little too. üòâ

In reality, maybe it‚Äôs not the time for me to entertain, but there is still time for me to be hospitable. I can still have people over to my house, and I can show hospitality to others even when I‚Äôm out and about by just having a welcoming spirit. I don‚Äôt have to have a big spread of food or send out formal invitations to create community. It might mean I make this chicken recipe and some good ol baked potatoes, or maybe we just pick up BBQ and hang out with friends after Mav goes to bed. It‚Äôs easy to make excuses and find reasons why ‚Äúwe can‚Äôt,‚Äù but the bottom line is we all need each other. Heck, sometimes I just need to talk to someone other than Maverick and Zach. Haha! And I‚Äôm thinking I‚Äôm not alone. People want to feel safe and comfortable, and I believe that happens most at the home of someone (like me) where a laundry basket of clothes is waiting to be folded in the corner and a Boppy gets used as a couch throw pillow.

To entertain, I may have to get everything pretty and perfect, but to be hospitable all I have to do is say, come on in!

Therefore welcome one another as Christ has welcomed you, for the glory of God. Romans 15:7

Now that that‚Äôs settled, back to my chicken legs, which are super easy and baked in the oven, making them perfect for when you‚Äôre being hospitable. No running in and out to check the grill and plenty of time to socialize while they bake! They also get slathered with an ooey,gooey sauce that is sticky and sweet and just plain yummy.

Also, shameless plug, the recipes in my cookbook are also perfect for showing hospitality this summer! Seriously, they are easy and uncomplicated, so no need to stress over food when you want to invite others to hang out and enjoy a meal on your patio. Bonus! Outdoor eating, means not so much cleaning!

Have you preordered the The Outdoor Table yet?! Click here to reserve your copy now!

Sticky Sesame Chicken Legs

Serves 4-5 (recipes may be easily doubled)

Ingredients

2 lbs chicken legs

1/4 cup dark brown sugar

1/4 cup molasses

1/4 cup soy sauce

2 tablespoons rice wine vinegar

1 tablespoon Siracha (find in Asaian seciotn on grocery)

1 teaspoon Sesame oil (find in Asian section of grocery)

Directions

Place the chicken legs in a large ziploc bag.

In a small bowl mix together the brown sugar, molasses, soy sauce, rice wine vinegar, siracha, and sesame oil. Pour this mixture into the bag, and marinate overnight or at least 2 hours.

Preheat the oven to 400 degrees.

Place aluminum foil over a baking sheet, and place a wire rack on top of the sheet. Use tongs to place the chicken legs on top of the rack and pour the remaining marinade in a small saucepan.

Bake the chicken legs for 30 minutes.

Meanwhile, bring the marinade to a simmer for about 10 minutes until it thickens. Remove from the heat and set aside.

Once the chicken has baked, brush the legs with the thickened sauce and bake for 10 more minutes.

It‚Äôs official, I have on the most comfortable and ugliest combination of clothing that is possible. #Icepocalypse #fuzzysocks

It‚Äôs a funny thing being trapped in your own house for 6 days. You see, right before this ice storm we‚Äôve had in Nashville, I had a bad cold. When you‚Äôre sick with a baby you pretty much don‚Äôt leave the house if possible, so it has been 6 straight days of being home. Don‚Äôt judge me. Obviously, if you have older kids, you can get out and sled and play in the ice/snow combo, but with a baby you really can‚Äôt do that. My days have been spent trying to catch up on sleep, laundry, and getting a few work related things done all in between taking care of Maverick, in the comfort of my own home, in my pjs, of course. It really doesn‚Äôt sound too bad, but once day 3 hits, you just need something, a change, some make up, a trip to Target, a break from the monotony. However, that hasn‚Äôt really been possible in this predicament we are in.

Needless to say, I‚Äôve spent a lot of time staring at the TV and my phone. But on day 3 things just began to feel empty. Filling my time with little tasks, looking at everyone‚Äôs snow pictures, and catching up on my shows just started to get a little old. I was feeding Maverick that night, and I ran across the picture f the Christian men who were beheaded by ISIS. I looked at their faces. And I thought, what am I doing? Here I am just trying to distract myself from life with TV and social media. And men are being murdered for their faith. It‚Äôs not a movie or a show, it‚Äôs like real life. I just started to feel this emptiness creep in. That‚Äôs what happens when I don‚Äôt feel myself with Him. It‚Äôs so easy to distract and entertain myself even while stuck at home for so long. When social media and TV get old I can turn to online shopping, vacationing planning, or even recipe creating. Not that any of those things are bad, but I was leaving Him out.

I‚Äôm finishing up Annie Downs book ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs all be Brave,‚Äù and I just read about the rhythm of discipline. I usually read my ‚ÄúSheReadsTruth‚Äù study in the mornings, but lately I‚Äôve let the other apps on my phone take precedence, I had gotten out of my rhythm. It‚Äôs a small thing, but just filling my mind with a little truth everyday, taking the time to pray and just be with God fills me up.

All of the things, the houses, the money, the cars, the status, the looks, the clothes. They are empty. They are never enough. The more I get the more I want. When we moved to our home now, I thought we really had something. You know, a really nice house to be proud of. Sure, I‚Äôm still proud of it, but it‚Äôs sort of lost it‚Äôs luster, you know? Like I find myself looking at the bathroom thinking it‚Äôs really outdated. The floors we put in the living room are already so scratched up. We need a bigger rug. And so on. Just 2 years ago, I was so proud of it. Now it just doesn‚Äôt quite cut it? Things. They lose their sparkle quickly. They never satisfy. I‚Äôm not saying they are bad or that I won‚Äôt redo our bathroom, but it won‚Äôt fulfill me. In a year or two the styles will change and it won‚Äôt seem so fresh and new anymore. He makes things new. He satisfies, oh how easily I forget.
